title: Educational Illustrations: Early Tools, Sculpture & Hominin Anatomy
text:
This project showcases my original scientific ink illustrations of ancient tools, sculpture fragments, and Homo naledi mandibles. Created as part of my coursework in Biomedical Communications and Technology, these drawings combine scientific accuracy with a visual storytelling approach to support learning in anthropology, anatomy, and archaeology.
Each piece is drawn by hand and annotated to highlight key anatomical and structural features — such as tooth morphology, tool shapes, and proportional measurements.



This detailed illustration highlights multiple views of the Homo naledi holotype mandible, based on anatomical research from Berger et al. (2015).



Homo naledi mandible



Occlusal, anterior, and lateral views of the mandible with details of molar cusp pattern and measurements. Source: Berger et al. (2015), eLife.



The mandible (lower jawbone) of Homo naledi provides crucial insights into the species’ dietary habits and evolutionary relationships. Notably, the molar cusp patterns reflect adaptations for processing a diverse diet that likely included tough plant materials and possibly meat.
The mandible’s robust form and proportional measurements suggest a combination of primitive and derived traits, positioning Homo naledi as a unique species with a mosaic of characteristics bridging early hominins and modern humans. Understanding these anatomical details helps anthropologists trace the development of tool use, speech, and social behaviors in early human ancestors.





Two early tool illustrations highlighting flaking patterns and inferred grip/strike zones.





Tool 1 – Ink Drawing


Tool 1 – Hand-illustrated obsidian flake with flake scars.




Tool 2 – Ink Drawing


Tool 2 – Bilaterally flaked core with bifacial edge.




The stone tools depicted demonstrate early hominins’ advanced knapping skills, where flakes were deliberately removed to create sharp edges for cutting, scraping, and hunting.
Tool 1, an obsidian flake, shows distinct flake scars that reveal intentional shaping, indicating cognitive planning and manual dexterity.
Tool 2, a bifacially flaked core, highlights symmetrical shaping on both sides, improving grip and durability. These tools mark critical technological milestones in human evolution, reflecting the emergence of cultural transmission and adaptability to diverse environments.





A series of ink and pencil studies on early symbolic objects, including Venus figurines and cave carvings.





Front Facing


Front view of symbolic sculpture study.




Side Facing


Side profile showing volume and posture details.




These sculptural fragments represent some of the earliest known symbolic expressions by prehistoric humans. The Venus figurines and cave carvings likely served ritualistic or communicative functions, providing clues about social structures, fertility beliefs, and identity.
The volumetric details captured in these studies reveal how ancient artists manipulated form and posture to convey meaning, demonstrating an early cognitive ability for abstract thinking and cultural storytelling.






Use visual communication to teach anthropological and archaeological concepts

Combine anatomical proportion, measurement, and clarity in scientific illustration

Explore how ancient objects tell stories about early human cognition and culture






Berger, L. R., et al. (2015). Homo naledi, a new species of the genus Homo from the Dinaledi Chamber, South Africa.

title: Marta Skira - Portfolio
text:
Welcome to my portfolio! I’m a data-driven and creative problem solver with a background in Health Science, Biomedical Communications and Technology, and Visual Studies. I love combining data, design, and storytelling to build engaging digital experiences — whether it’s an e-learning module, a birdwatching data project, or a global air pollution data analysis.




Degree: Honours Bachelor of Science, Health Science (University of Toronto, 2024)

Minors: Biomedical Communications, Technology, and Visual Studies

Skills: Python, SQL, Tableau, Excel, ArcGIS, Adobe Illustrator

Focus Areas: Data, data visualization, e-learning design, urban analytics, and environmental science

Certifications:

Python for Data Analysis – LinkedIn Learning

SQL for Data Analysis – LinkedIn Learning

Data Science Foundations – LinkedIn Learning








An interactive learning experience featuring:

3D eye anatomy model
Research-based content on 4 major vision impairments
Multiple-choice and matching quizzes
Focus on accessibility and comprehension




Used ArcGIS and population data to:

Map land use and zoning efficiency
Identify underutilized areas
Propose traffic solutions for growing urban zones




An innovative collar design for animals that:

Uses a microcontroller and Bluetooth on a collar or harness
Interacts with a home-based scanner to alert the owner
Integrates real-time notifications using visual and physical notifications




Analyzed air quality from 7,812 cities using Python:

Visualized PM2.5 and AQI data trends
Identified top pollutant contributors
Suggested targeted interventions for high-risk regions




A visual and auditory guide to learning bird anatomy and identification — powered by interactive quizzes and field data.






Email: martaskira2@gmail.com

LinkedIn: linkedin.com/in/martaskira

GitHub: github.com/martaskira

Thanks for stopping by! Feel free to explore my work and reach out if you’d like to collaborate on data-driven learning experiences or research-focused projects.

© 2025 Marta Skira. Built with ❤️ using Quarto.

title: Urban Planning and Land Use Analysis Using GIS
text:

title: Urban Planning and Land Use Analysis Using GIS
text:
Project Overview
In 2023, I conducted an urban planning and land use analysis for the City of Toronto using GIS data. The goal of the project was to identify underutilized land zones, optimize transportation corridors, and predict future urban infrastructure needs. This was achieved by integrating multiple datasets, performing spatial analysis using QGIS and Python, and developing actionable recommendations for urban development.

Key Project Objectives:

Identify underutilized land based on zoning, density, and FAR metrics.
Optimize transportation corridors by analyzing traffic congestion and predicting future trends.
Forecast future urban infrastructure needs considering population growth and expansion.

title: Urban Planning and Land Use Analysis Using GIS
text:
Data Sources
For this analysis, I used the following datasets:

Satellite imagery of Toronto (2023) for land cover and built-up areas.
City zoning GIS layers for categorizing land into residential, commercial, industrial, parks, and other zones.
Road network datasets to assess traffic flow and congestion.
Public transit stop locations (TTC) to understand access to public transport.
Population projections (2023–2041) to predict future urban growth and infrastructure needs.

title: Urban Planning and Land Use Analysis Using GIS
text:
Methodology

Step 1: Data Integration
I integrated over 15 GIS layers in both QGIS and Python (using GeoPandas) to create a comprehensive spatial dataset. This process included importing data related to zoning, road networks, transit stations, and population density.


Step 2: Land Categorization
I categorized the land into five major use zones:

Residential
Commercial
Industrial
Parks
Institutional



Step 3: Identification of Underutilized Land
Using Floor Area Ratio (FAR) metrics, I identified 18 underutilized land parcels in key areas of Toronto. FAR is a common urban planning metric that compares the total floor area of a building to the size of the land parcel. By identifying underutilized land, I was able to recommend potential areas for rezoning and development.


Step 4: Traffic Congestion Analysis
I analyzed traffic congestion projections based on the current road network and predicted population growth. Using this data, I identified five major transportation corridors that would benefit from upgrades such as road widening, improved traffic signal management, and public transit enhancements.


Step 5: Future Urban Infrastructure Needs
By using population projections from 2023 to 2041 and analyzing trends in land use and development, I was able to forecast future housing, utilities, and transportation infrastructure needs. This prediction will help Toronto’s city planners make informed decisions on where to allocate resources for urban development.

title: Urban Planning and Land Use Analysis Using GIS
text:
Key Findings

22% potential increase in land-use efficiency by rezoning underutilized land.
35% projected reduction in traffic congestion by improving transportation infrastructure.
Priority areas for future development were identified, along with the need for additional green spaces and public parks in high-density areas.

title: Urban Planning and Land Use Analysis Using GIS
text:
Visualizing the Data

Population Density Heatmap
Here is a heatmap showing population density across Toronto, highlighting areas where urban development should be prioritized.

title: Urban Planning and Land Use Analysis Using GIS
text:
Traffic Congestion Reduction
This bar chart visualizes the projected reduction in traffic congestion for key transportation corridors after proposed upgrades.





Traffic Congestion Reduction After Proposed Upgrades

title: Urban Planning and Land Use Analysis Using GIS
text:
Proposed Land Use Distribution
The donut chart below illustrates the proposed land-use distribution after optimization. The focus is on creating a balance between residential, commercial, and green spaces.





Proposed Land Use Distribution After Optimization

title: Urban Planning and Land Use Analysis Using GIS
text:
Proposed Solutions
Based on the analysis, the following solutions have been proposed to address Toronto’s urban planning and land use needs:

Mixed-Use Developments: Combining residential, commercial, and green spaces in high-density areas to improve land use efficiency.
Public Transit Expansion: Building new transit lines and expanding existing ones to reduce traffic congestion and improve accessibility.
Public Parks Development: Creating more parks in densely populated areas to provide green spaces for residents and improve quality of life.
Road Widening & Traffic Signal Optimization: Expanding key roads and optimizing traffic flow in critical corridors to reduce congestion.

title: Urban Planning and Land Use Analysis Using GIS
text:
Conclusion
This project demonstrates how data-driven analysis and GIS tools can significantly contribute to urban planning and land use optimization. By focusing on underutilized land, enhancing transportation networks, and forecasting future needs, we can make more informed decisions that will improve Toronto’s infrastructure and the quality of life for its residents.

title: Vision Impairments E-Learning Modulem
text: This interactive educational module is designed to teach learners about common vision impairments in adults over 40. It was built as part of my digital learning design work and combines 3D visuals, scientific research, and memory-boosting quizzes.

title: Vision Impairments E-Learning Modulem
text:
🧠 Project Overview

Topic: Common vision impairments in adults


Features:

Interactive eye anatomy model
Descriptions of 4 major vision impairments
Risk factors, corrections, and treatment options
Multiple-choice and matching quizzes
Accessibility-focused design



Tools Used:

H5P
Blender (for 3D model)
HTML
Quarto

The module includes:

Clickable eye diagram for exploring parts of the eye
3D embedded model to visualize how vision works
Quizzes to reinforce learning and improve recall

title: Vision Impairments E-Learning Modulem
text:
🎯 Learning Outcomes
By the end of this module, viewers will be able to:

Identify parts of the eye and understand the process behind vision.
Understand what vision impairments are and identify the most common ones in adults.
Visualize how vision impairments affect perception compared to normal vision.
Identify common risk factors for each impairment.
Understand ways to reduce the chances of developing impairments.
Recognize available treatment options.

title: Vision Impairments E-Learning Modulem
section: Let’s take a look at what the eye looks like inside!
text:
Let’s take a look at what the eye looks like inside!
Click and drag around the eye to see the difference components!

title: Vision Impairments E-Learning Modulem
text:
👁️ What Are Vision Impairments?
Visual impairment is a term for any kind of vision loss, whether it’s complete blindness or partial vision loss. Some people are born with visual impairments, while others develop them later in life.
(Source: KidsHealth)

title: Vision Impairments E-Learning Modulem
text:
🧠 How Eyes Work
When light hits the retina in the back of your eye, it’s converted into electrical signals that your optic nerve sends to your brain. Your brain turns these signals into the images you see.
(Source: NEI - How Eyes Work)

title: Vision Impairments E-Learning Modulem
text: 🔬 Eye Anatomy

title: Vision Impairments E-Learning Modulem
text: 🧪 Quiz: Eye Anatomy & Vision Basics

title: Vision Impairments E-Learning Modulem
text:
🧓 Common Vision Impairments

🔹 Blurred Vision (Refractive Errors)
What is it? A refractive error means your eye can’t bend light properly, leading to blurry vision.
- Types: Myopia (nearsightedness) and hyperopia (farsightedness)


 Sight with Myopia

 Sight with Hyperopia



Risk Factors: Age, Genetics

Corrections: Glasses, Contact lenses, Refractive surgery (LASIK)
(Source: UM Kellogg Eye Center)




🔹 Age-Related Macular Degeneration (AMD)
What is it? Damage to the macula, the part of the retina responsible for sharp central vision.

Types: Dry form and wet form



  Sight with AMD






🧪 Dry Form AMD





💧 Wet Form AMD







Risk Factors: Age (50+), Smoking, Family history

Corrections: Vitamin supplements, Laser therapy, Injections
(Source: UM Kellogg Eye Center - AMD)



🔹 Glaucoma
What is it? A group of diseases that damage the eye’s optic nerve, often due to high eye pressure.

Types: Open-angle, Closed-angle



  Sight with glaucoma






🔒 Close Angle Glaucoma





👁️ Open Angle Glaucoma







Risk Factors: Age, Family history, High eye pressure

Corrections: Eye drops, Laser treatment, Surgery
(Source: UM Kellogg Eye Center - Glaucoma)



🔹 Cataract
What is it? Clouding of the eye’s lens, leading to blurry or dim vision


  Sight with cataract



Risk Factors: Aging, Diabetes, UV exposure

Corrections: Lens replacement surgery
(Source: UM Kellogg Eye Center - Cataract)

title: Vision Impairments E-Learning Modulem
text: 🧪 Quiz: Vision Impairments

title: Vision Impairments E-Learning Modulem
text:
💬 Reflections
Creating this module helped me strengthen my ability to:

Translate complex scientific topics into accessible language
Build interactive digital learning tools
Balance visual communication with pedagogical structure

title: Feline-On-Board (FOB): A Bluetooth Cat Proximity Alert System
text: Feline-On-Board (FOB) is a digital design prototype developed for outdoor pet cats. The system is designed to sit on a collar or harness and alert owners when their cat enters the vicinity of their home, making it easier for owners to know when to let their pet inside. The project leverages Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) technology, with a beacon on the cat and a scanner at home that detects the beacon’s presence.

title: Feline-On-Board (FOB): A Bluetooth Cat Proximity Alert System
text: Feline-On-Board (FOB) is a digital design prototype developed for outdoor pet cats. The system is designed to sit on a collar or harness and alert owners when their cat enters the vicinity of their home, making it easier for owners to know when to let their pet inside. The project leverages Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) technology, with a beacon on the cat and a scanner at home that detects the beacon’s presence.

title: Feline-On-Board (FOB): A Bluetooth Cat Proximity Alert System
text:
Project Objectives

Create a wearable Bluetooth beacon for a cat’s collar or harness.
Develop a home-based scanner to detect the beacon and alert the owner.
Demonstrate real-time detection with a visual (TFT display) and physical (LED) notification.
Ensure the design is compact, portable, and minimally disruptive to the cat.

title: Feline-On-Board (FOB): A Bluetooth Cat Proximity Alert System
text:
Methodology

Hardware

Cat Beacon:

Board: Adafruit ESP32-S3 QT Py

Power: Button batteries or portable charger

Enclosure: Custom case lined with silicone for waterproofing

Home Scanner:

Board: Adafruit ESP32-S3 Feather

Power: 3x AA batteries in a holder (4.5V)

Display: TFT display for beacon info

Notification: Red LED for proximity alert




Design Process

Initial Concept:

Beacon on collar or harness, smartphone as scanner.




 Collar Prototype

 Harness Prototype



Prototype Evolution:

Switched to ESP32 Feather as scanner for greater customization.
Added TFT display and LED for clear feedback.

Enclosure Prototyping:

Two versions: compact (QT Py + button batteries) and larger (Feather + AA batteries).
Silicone lining for water protection.

Power Solutions:

Portable charger used for beacon due to wiring challenges with batteries.

title: Feline-On-Board (FOB): A Bluetooth Cat Proximity Alert System
text:
Technical Implementation

BLE Beacon (QT Py Board)

Uses iBeacon protocol with custom device name “Cat_Beacon”.
Broadcasts unique UUID for identification.
Powered by portable charger for demonstration reliability.

title: Feline-On-Board (FOB): A Bluetooth Cat Proximity Alert System
text:
Demonstration

Live Demo:

Showed beacon entering and leaving scanner range.
TFT displayed “Cat_Beacon” and signal strength.
Red LED illuminated when cat (beacon) was close.




 Close Proximity

 Far Proximity



Key Features:

Real-time updates with a few seconds’ delay.
Portable charger used for beacon during demo due to battery wiring issues.
Compact collar prototype displayed for audience.

title: Feline-On-Board (FOB): A Bluetooth Cat Proximity Alert System
text:
Results & Limitations

Successes:

Reliable detection within a few meters.
Clear visual and physical notifications.
Compact, waterproofed design feasible for real-world use.

Limitations:

Detection range limited to a single room (a few meters).
Battery wiring for beacon was challenging; portable charger used as workaround.
Delay in detection and LED response (a few seconds).
Interference from other Bluetooth devices can affect detection.

title: Feline-On-Board (FOB): A Bluetooth Cat Proximity Alert System
text:
Reflections & Lessons Learned

Tutorials on Arduino and Feather board were crucial for rapid prototyping.
Serial monitor helped debug and verify beacon transmissions.
The project was inspired by self-tracking concepts and the idea of using technology for pet care.
Future improvements:

Increase detection range and reduce delay.
Refine battery integration for true portability.
Further miniaturize and waterproof the enclosure.

title: Feline-On-Board (FOB): A Bluetooth Cat Proximity Alert System
text:
Conclusion
Feline-On-Board demonstrates how physical computing and IoT can be applied to everyday challenges, such as pet monitoring. The project successfully integrates hardware, firmware, and user feedback to create a functional prototype that can be further developed for real-world use.

*For more technical details, see the full code and design files on:

BLE Beacon Code (BLE_Server.ino)
Bluetooth Scanner Code (Scanner_TFT_Display.ino)

title: About
text: This website is my creative space—a place where I bring together my projects, passions, and curiosity. From interactive learning modules to visual storytelling, each piece here reflects my interest in making complex ideas more accessible and engaging. Whether I’m exploring science through design, building digital tools, or experimenting with new platforms, this site is my way of sharing what I’m learning and creating along the way.
